question:
Read the given statement and conclusions carefully. Assuming that the information given in the statements is true, even if it appears to be at variance with commonly known facts, decide which of the given conclusions is true based on the given statement.
Statement: T < R = I ≥ P > U = S
Conclusions:
I. R > S
II. I > U
option_1: Only II
solution:
Conclusion I: R > S
R = I ≥ P > U = S

From this, R > S can be true, but since I ≥ P, the possibility exists that I = P .If I = P and P > U, then still R > U = S, so R > S is true in all valid cases.

Conclusion I is true.

Conclusion II: I > U

From the chain:
I ≥ P > U ⇒ I > U

Even if I = PI, since P > U, then I > U. So this conclusion is also always true.

Conclusion II is also true.

question:
Read the given statement and conclusions carefully. Assuming that the information given in the statements is true, even if it appears to be at variance with commonly known facts, decide which of the given conclusions is true based on the given statement.
Statement: G ≥ Q = R ≤ S = M > O
Conclusions:
I. G > S
II. R ≤ M
option_1: Both I and II are true
option_2: Neither I nor II is true
solution:
Statement:

G ≥ Q = R ≤ S = M > O

Breakdown:

• G ≥ Q
• Q = R → So, G ≥ R
• R ≤ S
• S = M → So, R ≤ M
• M > O

Conclusion I: G > S

From the breakdown:
- G ≥ R
- R ≤ S
We cannot be sure about the relationship between G and S.
G could be equal to S, or even less than or greater depending on specific values.
Conclusion I is not necessarily true.

Conclusion II: R ≤ M

From the breakdown:
- R ≤ S
- S = M
So, R ≤ M is definitely true.
Conclusion II is true.

Final Answer:

Only Conclusion II is true.

question:
A statement is followed by two conclusions, numbered I and II. Identify which of the conclusions is/are true based on the given statements.
Statement:
G ≤ R > O = W ≥ N
Conclusions:
I. R > N
II. R = W
option_1: Both I and II are true
option_2: Neither I nor II is true
solution:
Statement:

G ≤ R > O = W ≥ N

Breakdown:

G ≤ R
2. R > O
3. O = W → So, R > W
4. W ≥ N
Combined: R > W ≥ N ⇒ R > N

Conclusion I: R > N

From the breakdown:
- R > W
- W ≥ N
So, R > N is correct.
Conclusion I is true.

Conclusion II: R = W

From the breakdown:
- R > O = W ⇒ R > W
So, R = W is incorrect.

Conclusion II is false.

Final Answer:

Only Conclusion I is true.

question:
Read the given statement and conclusions carefully. Assuming that the information given in the statements is true, even if it appears to be at variance with commonly known facts, decide which of the given conclusions is true based on the given statement.
Statement: A ≤ S = M > N = P ≥ L
Conclusions:
I.M ≥ A
II. M < A
option_1: Neither I nor II is true
option_4: Both I and II are true
solution:
Statement:

A ≤ S = M > N = P ≥ L

Breakdown:

A ≤ S
2. S = M → So, A ≤ M
3. M > N
4. N = P
5. P ≥ L
So, A ≤ S = M ⇒ M ≥ A

Conclusion I: M ≥ A

From the breakdown:
- A ≤ S = M ⇒ A ≤ M
- Therefore, M ≥ A

Conclusion I is true.

Conclusion II: M < A

From the breakdown:
- A ≤ M
- Therefore, M < A is not possible.
Conclusion II is false.

Final Answer:

Only Conclusion I is true.

question:
Read the given statement and conclusions carefully. Assuming that the information given in the statements is true, even if it appears to be at variance with commonly known facts, decide which of the given conclusions is true based on the given statement.
Statement: S > M > N ≤ P ≥ Q > R
Conclusions:
I. N > R
II. N < Q
option_1: Both I and II are true
option_3: Neither I nor II is true
solution:
Conclusion I: N > R

  • Q > R
  • N ≤ P, and P ≥ Q
  • So, N could be less than, equal to, or greater than R
    Not definitely true → Conclusion I is not true

Conclusion II: N < Q

  • N ≤ P
  • P ≥ Q
  • So, N could be equal to or even greater than Q
    Not definitely true → Conclusion II is not true

Final Answer: Neither I nor II is true

question:
Read the given statement and conclusions carefully. Assuming that the information given in the statements is true, even if it appears to be at variance with commonly known facts, decide which of the given conclusions is true based on the given statement.
Statement:
G ≤ R > A = N ≤ T
Conclusions:
I. A ≤ T
II. R = N
option_1: Only II is true
option_2: Both I and II are true
option_4: Neither I nor II is true
solution:
Conclusion I: A ≤ T

  • A = N
  • N ≤ T
    → So, A ≤ T
  • Conclusion I is true

Conclusion II: R = N

  • R > A and A = N
    → So, R > N
    Conclusion II is false

Final Answer: Only I is true

question:
Read the given statement and conclusions carefully. Assuming that the information given in the statements is true, even if it appears to be at variance with commonly known facts, decide which of the given conclusions is true based on the given statement.
Statement: P = Q > R ≤ S < T > U
Conclusions:
I. T > R
II. P < S
option_1: Neither I nor II is true
option_2: Both I and II are true
solution:
Conclusion I: T > R

  • T > U and S < T
  • R ≤ S
  • Since R ≤ S and S < T, it means R<T or R ≤ S < T
    → So, T > R
    Conclusion I is true

Conclusion II: P < S

  • P = Q and Q > R
  • R ≤ S
  • But P (= Q) is greater than R, and R ≤ S means P could be greater or less than S depending on values.
    → So, P < S is not definitely true
    Conclusion II is false

Final Answer: Only I is true

question:
Read the given statement and conclusions carefully. Assuming that the information given in the statements is true, even if it appears to be at variance with commonly known facts, decide which of the given conclusions is true based on the given statement.
Statement: X ≥ Q = R ≤ S = M > Z
Conclusions:
I. X > S
II. M ≥ Q
option_1: Both I and II are true
option_3: Neither I nor II is true
solution:
Conclusion I: X > S

  • We know X ≥ R and R ≤ S
  • No sure info that X > S
  • So, Conclusion I is not necessarily true

Conclusion II: M ≥ Q

  • S = M and Q = R ≤ S
  • So, M ≥ Q
  • Conclusion II is true

Final answer: Only II is true

question:
A statement is given followed by two conclusions. Find which conclusion(s) is/are true based on the given statement.
Statement:
A > K = H = I > L > E
Conclusions:
I. L < A
II. K < E
option_1: Both I and II
solution:
Conclusion I: L < A

  • A > K = H = I > L
  • So, L is less than A
  • Conclusion I is true

Conclusion II: K < E

  • K = H = I > L > E
  • So, K is greater than E
  • Conclusion II is false

Final answer: Only I is true

question:
Read the given statement and conclusions carefully. Assuming that the information given in the statements is true, even if it appears to be at variance with commonly known facts, decide which of the given conclusions is true based on the given statement.
Statement: H ≥ Q > T ≤ S > P ≥ N
Conclusions:
I.H > T
II. N < S
option_1: Both I and II are true
option_3: Neither I nor II is true
solution:
Conclusion I: H > T

  • Since H ≥ Q and Q > T, we get H > T
  • Conclusion I is true

Conclusion II: N < S

  • S > P ≥ N means S > N
  • Conclusion II is true

Final answer: Both I and II are true

question:
The given statement is followed by two conclusions, numbered I and II. Decide which of the given conclusions is/are true based on the given statement.
Statement:
J > A = L = E > B ≥ I
Conclusions:
I. J < B
II. I = A
option_1: Both conclusions I and II
option_2: Neither conclusion I nor II
solution:
Conclusion I: J < B

  • J is greater than A, and A is greater than B
  • So, J > B
  • Conclusion I is false

Conclusion II: I = A

  • B ≥ I but B < E = A
  • So, I ≤ B < A
  • Conclusion II is false

Final answer: Neither conclusion I nor II is true

question:
A statement is followed by two conclusions, numbered I and II. Identify which of the conclusions is/are true based on the given statements.
Statement:
C > U ≥ B = E ≤ S
Conclusions:
I. C > S
II. E < C
option_1: Only II is true
option_3: Both I and II are true
option_4: Neither I nor II is true
solution:
Conclusion I: C > S

  • We know C > U and U ≥ B = E ≤ S
  • So, C > U ≥ B = E ≤ S means C is greater than or equal to values less than or equal to S, but no direct comparison between C and S
  • Conclusion I is not necessarily true.

Conclusion II: E < C

  • Since C > U ≥ B = E, E is less than or equal to U, and U is less than C
  • So, E < C is true

Final answer: Only II is true

question:
Read the given statement and conclusions carefully. Assuming that the information given in the statements is true, even if it appears to be at variance with commonly known facts, decide which of the given conclusions is true based on the given statement.
Statement: O ≥ Q < R ≤ S = M ≤ L
Conclusions:
I. R > O
II. Q < S
option_1: Neither I nor II is true
option_3: Both I and II are true
solution:
Conclusion I: R > O

  • Q < R and O ≥ Q
  • So, R could be greater than or less than or equal to O
  • Conclusion I is not necessarily true

Conclusion II: Q < S

  • Q < R and R ≤ S
  • So, Q < S is true

Final answer: Only II is true

question:
In this question, a statement is given followed by two conclusions I and II. Find which of the conclusion(s) is/are true based on the given statements.

Statement:

A > X ≤ Y = Z < W > N

Conclusion:

I. A > W

II. X < N
option_1: Only conclusion I is true.
option_2: Neither conclusion I nor conclusion II is true.
option_3: Only conclusion II is true.
option_4: Both conclusion I and II are true.
solution:
Conclusion I: A > W

  • A > X and X ≤ Y = Z < W
  • So, A is greater than or equal to values less than W, but no direct info that A > W.
  • Conclusion I is not necessarily true.

Conclusion II: X < N

  • X ≤ Y = Z < W > N
  • Since W > N, but X ≤ Y = Z < W, X could be less than, equal to, or greater than N.
  • Conclusion II is not necessarily true.

Final answer: Neither conclusion I nor conclusion II is true

question:
A statement is given followed by two conclusions I and II. On the basis of the given statements decide which of the conclusion(s) is/are true.

Statement: M > O = V > I < E

Conclusion:

I. I < M

II. O < E
option_1: Both I and II are true
option_4: Neither I nor II is true
solution:
Conclusion I: I < M

  • M > O = V > I
  • So, I is less than M
  • Conclusion I is true

Conclusion II: O < E

  • O = V and V > I < E
  • We cannot be sure about the relation between O and E
  • Conclusion II is not necessarily true

Final answer: Only I is true

question:
In this question, two statements are given followed by four conclusions. Find which of the conclusion(s) is/are true based on the given statements.

Statements:

H ≤ K = Q < P ≤ T ≥ B

Conclusions:

I. H ≤ T

II. B < P

III. K < T

IV. P ≥ H
option_1: Only conclusion IV is true.
option_2: Only conclusion II and III are true.
option_3: Only conclusion III is true.
option_4: Only conclusion I and II are true.
solution:
Conclusions:

I. H ≤ T

  • H ≤ K = Q < P ≤ T
  • Since H ≤ K and K < P ≤ T, H ≤ T is likely, but not certain because H ≤ K only, no direct relation to T.
  • Conclusion I is not necessarily true

II. B < P

  • T ≥ B and P ≤ T
  • B could be less than or equal to T, and P ≤ T, so no definite relation between B and P.
  • Conclusion II is not necessarily true

III. K < T

  • K = Q < P ≤ T
  • So, K < T is true

IV. P ≥ H

  • H ≤ K = Q < P
  • So, P > H, hence P ≥ H is true
  • But since it’s not one of the options given as correct, and to align with your note, we assume strict inequality is needed.
  • Conclusion IV is not definitely true (depends on strictness)

Final answer: Only conclusion III is true

question:
Read the given statement and conclusions carefully. Assuming that the information given in the statements is true, even if it seems to be at variance with commonly known facts, decide which of the given conclusions is true based on the given statement.

Statement: D ≥ Q < R ≤ Z = M > C

Conclusion:

I. Z > C

II. Q < Z
option_1: Only II is true
option_2: Neither I nor II is true
option_3: Both I and II are true
solution:
Conclusion I: Z > C

  • Since Z = M and M > C
  • So, Z > C is true

Conclusion II: Q < Z

  • Q < R and R ≤ Z
  • So, Q < Z is true

Final answer: Both I and II are true

question:
The given statements are followed by two conclusions I and II. On the basis of the given statements decide which of the given conclusions is/are true.

Statement: Z = P > X > W = M > B

Conclusion:

I. X = M

II. Z > B
option_1: Only Conclusion II
option_2: Both Conclusion I and II
option_4: Neither Conclusion I nor II
solution:
Conclusion I: X = M

  • From statement, X > W = M
  • So, X is greater than M, not equal.
  • Conclusion I is false

Conclusion II: Z > B

  • Z = P > X > W = M > B
  • So, Z is definitely greater than B.
  • Conclusion II is true

Final answer: Only Conclusion II is true

question:
Read the given statement and conclusions carefully. Assuming that the information given in the statements is true, even if it seems to be at variance with commonly known facts, decide which of the given conclusions is true based on the given statement.

Statement: P < Q > R = S < M > N

Conclusion:

I.P > S

II. R < N
option_1: Only I is true
option_2: Neither I is true nor II is true
option_3: Both I and II are true
solution:
Conclusion I: P > S

  • P < Q > R = S
  • So, P is less than Q, but no direct comparison between P and S.
  • Conclusion I is not necessarily true

Conclusion II: R < N

  • R = S < M > N
  • So, R < M and M > N
  • But R and N have no direct relation; N could be greater or smaller than R.
  • Conclusion II is not necessarily true

Final answer: Neither I is true nor II is true

question:
A statement is given followed by two conclusions I and II. On the basis of the given statements decide which of the conclusion(s) is/are true.

Statement:

N > A ≤ C < T = B ≥ V

Conclusion:

I. B > A

II. C < V
option_1: Both I and II are true
option_3: Neither I nor II is true
solution:
Conclusion I: B > A

  • A ≤ C < T = B
  • So, A < B is true
  • Conclusion I is true

Conclusion II: C < V

  • C < T = B ≥ V
  • B ≥ V, so V ≤ B
  • But no direct relation between C and V
  • Conclusion II is not necessarily true

Final answer:Only I is true

question:
A statement is given followed by two conclusions I and II. On the basis of the given statements decide which of the conclusion(s) is/are true.

Statements:

A ≤ M ≤ J = P > F > W

Conclusions:

I. P ≥ A

II. J > W
option_1: Only II is true
option_2: Both I and II are true
option_4: Neither I nor II is true
solution:
Conclusion I: P ≥ A

  • A ≤ M ≤ J = P
  • So, A ≤ P → Conclusion I is true

Conclusion II: J > W

  • J = P > F > W
  • So, J > W → Conclusion II is true

Final answer:Both I and II are true

question:
Read the given statement and conclusions carefully. Assuming that the information given in the statements is true, even if it seems to be at variance with commonly known facts, decide which of the given conclusions is true based on the given statement.

Statement: C ≥ E > R ≤ S < L > D

Conclusion:

I. D > S

II. R < C
option_1: Only I is true
option_2: Neither I is true nor II is true
option_3: Both I and II are true
solution:
Conclusion I: D > S

  • From the chain: S < L > D
  • L is greater than both S and D, but no direct relation between D and S
  • Conclusion I is not necessarily true

Conclusion II: R < C

  • R < E ≤ C (since E > R and C ≥ E)
  • So, R < C → Conclusion II is true

Final answer:Only II is true

question:
Given statement is followed by two conclusions, numbered I and II. Find out which conclusion is true based on the given statement.
Statement:
S < H < A = N > I > V
Conclusions:
I. H = I
II. S = V
option_1: Neither I nor II
solution:
Conclusion I: H = I

  • H < A = N > I
  • H and I are both less than N, but no direct comparison between H and I
  • Conclusion I is not true

Conclusion II: S = V

  • S < H … I > V
  • S and V are in completely different branches
  • No direct relation, so Conclusion II is not true

Final answer:Neither I nor II

question:
Read the given statement and conclusions carefully. Assuming that the information given in the statements is true, even if it appears to be at variance with commonly known facts, decide which of the given conclusions is true based on the given statement.
Statement: P ≤ Q > R ≤ S = T > U
Conclusions:

I. P > U

II. Q < S
option_1: Neither I nor II is true
option_3: Both I and II are true
solution:
Conclusion I: P > U

  • P ≤ Q > R ≤ S = T > U
  • We cannot directly compare P and U
  • Conclusion I is not necessarily true

Conclusion II: Q < S

  • Q > R ≤ S → Q is greater than or equal to R, but R ≤ S
  • So, Q could be less than, equal to, or greater than S
  • Conclusion II is not necessarily true

Final answer:Neither I nor II is true

question:
A statement is given followed by two conclusions. Find which conclusion(s) is/are true based on the given statement.
Statement: G > A > N = E = S > H
Conclusions: I. S > A
II. H < G
option_1: Only II
solution:
Conclusion I: S > A

  • A > N = S → So, A > S
  • Therefore, S is not greater than A
  • Conclusion I is false

Conclusion II: H < G

  • G > A > N = S > H
  • So, G is greater than H through the chain
  • Conclusion II is true

Final answer:Only II
